newsitem.title: UK: China's booming TV market looks to advertising.
newsitem.headline: China's booming TV market looks to advertising.

text.p: China's television market, the world's biggest in terms of viewers, is expanding rapidly into cable and depending increasingly on advertising, a report released on Tuesday said.
Zenith Media said in its report on television in Asia that 73 percent of all homes in China were believed to have television, suggesting a staggering potential audience of 875 million people.
It said television was China's most popular medium and that television revenue soared by 65 percent in 1995 and total advertising expenditure by 53 percent.

"Advertising revenue has flooded in" since television in China was partly deregulated in 1987, said Zenith, the media-planning and buying arm of Cordiant Plc, said it its report "Television in Asia Pacific to 2001".
Zenith said China had 980 terrestrial TV channels, comprising eight nationwide, 73 provincial, 499 county and 400 city channels.
It said people in Beijing watched an average 158 minutes of television each day.
"Government subsidy has virtually disappeared from national and provincial television, and is ebbing away from the cities, replaced by advertising revenue," Zenith said.
"Financial independence is much greater than television's editorial independence, but (TV) is no longer simply an agent of state propaganda," it said.
Zenith said political documentaries that used to take up a lot of television airtime have given way to drama, movies, sport and entertainment.
Until 1992 China's television marketplace was basically confined to the provinces of Beijing, Shanghai and Guangdong.
But by 1996, the three provinces, while still representing the main market, accounted for only a third of the money spent on television throughout China.

Zenith said a larger proportion of money was being spent in other provinces due to competition for advertising budgets, rising professionalism in the television world and popularity of local services.
Zenith said Chinese authorities had been keen to develop cable TV "as a bulwark against Western culture", hoping to hinder the spread of foreign satellite dishes by promoting local cable services.
Television airtime in China is cheap, with advertisers able to reach an average 1,000 viewers with each 10 to 50 cents they spend.
That so-called "cost-per-thousand" is barely five percent of the price for television airtime in Hong Kong, Zenith said.

Chinese authorities do not license foreign companies to participate in terrestrial television distribution, nor do they allow direct foreign investment in broadcasters of cable distributors, the report said.
"Multinationals wishing to tap into the potentially enormous Chinese television market have therefore concentrated on satellite television services," it said.
